awd_titl_txt: REU Site: Weather, Climate and Society: An Interdisciplinary Approach Integrating Physical and Social Sciences
awd_abstract_narration:
This Weather, Climate, and Society (WCS) REU program hosted by the University of South Florida (USF) is designed to prepare the next generation of undergraduates (UGs) to pursue STEM fields and become successful future graduate students and researchers. The REU will broaden participation of underrepresented groups by recruiting participants primarily from non-research institutions, including local Hispanic Serving Institutions and Historically Black Colleges and Universities. Focusing on rising sophomores, this REU program draws students into the STEM disciplines early in their career. Research projects will explore a range of issues from social and physical factors which affect hurricane evacuation decision making, to assessing the social, economic, and environmental vulnerabilities of coastal regions to sea level rise, and developing strategies to adapt and mitigate sea level rise impacts.  Each project will have the potential to directly benefit the west central Florida community, as well as disaster-vulnerable communities in other extreme weather¬ affected areas. USF's WCS REU will become a model for interdisciplinary-based research. 

The program, which draws from an interdisciplinary panel of mentors, is designed to achieve these objectives: 1) Deliver an intensive research experience for 10 undergraduates/year with an emphasis on under-represented groups; 2) Provide participants with research experiences to aid their recruitment into a STEM UG major, particularly the atmospheric sciences or a  related discipline, and graduate programs; 3) Promote participants' skill development through a program of mentored research, experiential learning, professional development workshops, remote seminars that offer interaction with national and international scientists, trainings in social and physical research techniques and interdisciplinary perspectives on social and physical aspects, and impacts of, severe weather and climate and related disasters; 4) Increase awareness of ethical issues related to working with scientific data and communicating the results; and 5) Provide UGs access to a mentoring network that will support them throughout their career.  Students will receive exposure to qualitative, quantitative, and mixed methods approaches, and tools such as geographic information systems (GIS), and use their acquired skills on mentored research projects. The NSF REU UGs will work in a team with other students, being co-mentored by faculty in both the physical and social science disciplines. Students will participate in a project from conception to presentation and dissemination of results. UGs will therefore be involved in all aspects of research, including field work, sample processing in the laboratory and data analysis, and manuscript preparation.

por.por_cntn:
We were highly successful in achieving full enrollment with 30 undergraduates from a variety of disciplines (mostly freshmen and a mix of STEM and non-STEM majors) who participated in the Weather, Climate, and Society (WCS) REU. Our efforts to recruit nationally, including an emphasis on under-represented populations, achieved a diverse composition of undergraduate participants including a large percentage of female, first generation college students, and racial/ethnic minorities (inc. African American, Hispanic, Native American). Each year we built new contacts and recruitment strengthened further so that 70% racial/ethnic minorities participated by year 3. We also recruited an African American Graduate Assistant (Yr 1 and 2) and a Pacific Islander Graduate Assistant (Yr. 3).

The WCS REU undergraduates were given intensive introductory instruction in research methods and tools. Several of these projects involved training in some basic statistical tests, and this instruction was provided in the bootcamps and then reinforced later by the mentors. The projects emphasized both physical and social science aspects of the research, and had significant community impact. All 30 students presented in the poster symposium where community guests were invited (the third year was virtual symposium due to COVID). Each student created their individual poster of their contribution to the group project. Many of these REU students presented at conferences including the CUR Research Experiences for Undergraduates programs (REUS), the Emerging Researchers National Conference, as well as discipline specific conferences such as the American Association of Geographers (AAG) and the American Meteorological Society, as well as specific conferences such as the Oklahoma University Water Conference. Several students presented at their home institutions. Groups submitted preliminary reports on their work in the summer to stakeholders such as emergency managers and regional planners across the state. Work from the REU was published (or is currently accepted or under review) which included REU students (who were mostly freshmen) including:

Collins, J.M., A. Polen, K. McSweeney, D. Colon Burgos, I. Jernigan, 2021. Hurricane Risk Perceptions and Evacuation Decision Making in the Age of COVID-19. Bulletin of The American Meteorological Society. https://doi.org/10.1175/BAMS-D-20-0229.1

Collins, J.M., A. Polen, I. Jernigan*, D. Col?n-Burgos*, K. McSweeney*, M. Spandri*. An Analysis of the Success of Virtual Research Experience for Undergraduates Programs in Light of the COVID-19 Pandemic. Accepted in Bulletin of The American Meteorological Society (September, 2021). 

Bartesaghi, M., L. Smithberger, K. Laurent*, K. Martinez*, & S. Stewart*, 2021. Sharpiegate: science, state and professional vision in the constitution of weather. Journal of Applied Linguistics in Professional Practice. (In review).

(note: * are REU students, underlined is grad student)

The students were further recognized after the REU and many received awards and internships including NASA DEVELOP, the NWS Pathways in several locations including Guam and National Weather Service Pacific Region Headquarters, and local organizations such as Tampa Bay Water. One student who came to us from a community college entered Fisk University, an HBCU, where she received a Provost Scholarship. Some students went on to undertake other REUs in the STEM field such as one student who participated in the Cornell Institute of Host-Microbe Interactions and Disease (CIHMID) Undergraduate Research Experience. Some students reported being on research teams since the REU and publishing with those teams. One for instance was a co-author with a renowned team of scientists with a paper titled, ?Dissolved inorganic carbon accumulating complexes from autotrophic bacteria from extreme environments?.

The students who were from the earlier cohorts have now graduated and many have reported being admitted into graduate school. One even reported, from the August 2021 surveys sent to all 30 students, that they have already completed a Masters in GIS through an accelerated degree place.  Some are going straight into a PhD program.
